Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the risk of hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China containing the coronavirus by not providing sufficient evidence or support.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence presented to prove that hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China actually contain the coronavirus.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus without providing any factual basis or evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations, such as the possibility that the hair extension factories in China temporarily closed due to fears of the coronavirus being a breeding ground, but not because the products themselves contain the virus.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence to support the transmission of COVID-19 associated with imported goods, as stated by the FDA and other agencies.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on an article from a site run by a radio personality, which has been flagged as false news and misinformation by Facebook.
Understate: None of the biases indicate an understatement in the claim.
